awd_titl_txt: NSF-BSF: Ion Transport in Composite Electrolytes: Breaking the Interfacial Energy Barriers
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract
Electrical energy storage is at the heart of everyday life. It is required for cell phones, laptops, standby power systems, electric vehicles, and other applications. Solid-state batteries, batteries that do not contain any liquid like most of today’s battery systems, have emerged as particularly promising solution. Ion conducting polymers combined with superionic ceramics are considered as the most promising materials for the solid electrolytes. With this project, funded by the Ceramics program in the Division of Materials Research, Professor Sokolov at the University of Tennessee, in collaboration with colleagues from Israel, studies fundamental mechanisms controlling ion transport in such composite polymer-ceramic materials. These two classes of materials have complimentary properties that up to now were not realized due to poor understanding of ion transport in disparate systems. The proposed research deepens our understanding of the mechanisms of ion conductivity and enables the design of composite electrolytes with required properties for solid state batteries and other energy storage devices. New energy storage systems are critical for many current and future technologies from electric vehicles to efficient renewable energy sources and could lead to a substantial decrease of the carbon emission. Additionally, this project allows postdoctoral scholars, graduate and undergraduate students to gain valuable experience in sophisticated experimental research and international collaborations. Outreach to K-12 students at and around the University of Tennessee is aimed at attracting more students to STEM careers.

Technical Abstract
The interfacial resistance between the ceramic and polymer phases strongly suppresses the ionic conductivity and presents the main obstacle for this type of solid-state electrolytes. The US-Israel international collaborative research, supported by the Ceramics program in the Division of Materials Research, focuses on developing a fundamental understanding of mechanisms controlling ion transport in polymer-ceramic composites, specifically on unraveling parameters controlling interfacial barriers for ion transport between ceramic and polymer electrolytes. A combination of dielectric spectroscopy, nuclear magnetic resonance and neutron scattering spectroscopy, complemented by microscopy is used to elucidate the fundamentals of the transport mechanism. The experimental research will deepen fundamental understanding of microscopic parameters controlling ion transport in composite electrolytes. Insights gained from studying layered ceramic-polymer electrolyte model systems have the potential to be instrumental for a rational design of novel solid-state electrolytes with required conductivity, flexibility and stability, as well as reframing the electrical energy storage technology by developing new materials. The knowledge gained might also have strong impact on other fields of materials science, including applied physics and chemistry, airspace composites and environmental sustainability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The future use of electrical energy storage in electric vehicles, renewable energy systems, and portable electronics necessitates significant advancements in current battery and supercapacitor technologies. The development of solid electrolytes could lead to a transformative breakthrough, enabling more efficient electrochemical processes and the creation of solid-state batteries with much higher energy density and enhanced safety. However, currently no existing material meets all the requirements for solid electrolytes, such as high ionic conductivity, favorable mechanical properties, flexibility, a wide electrochemical stability window, and strong electrode adhesion. In this context, ceramic-polymer composite electrolytes offer a promising solution that might combine good conductivity of ceramics with good mechanical and adhesion properties of polymers. However, substantial interfacial energy barrier for ion transport between ceramics and polymer remains the major obstacle in development of composite electrolytes with required conductivity. This project focused on developing fundamental understanding of mechanisms controlling ion transport in polymer-ceramic composites with special focus on reducing energy barrier for Li+ and Na+ transport between ceramics and polymers.

In the current project in collaboration with Israeli team, we developed original technology for fabricating composite electrolyte films with extremely high (up to 97 wt%) ceramic content. These so-called polymer-in-ceramic composites were produced using electrophoretic deposition. The developed technology might have implications for synthesis of other polymer composite materials with extremely high content of fillers.

We developed a procedure for estimates of interfacial polymer-ceramic resistance using tri-layer structure with a ceramic disc sandwiched between two thin (~12 microns) layers of polymer electrolyte. The developed approach reduces the bulk polymer resistance enabling better access to the polymer-ceramic interfacial resistance. Using the developed tri-layer system, we discovered that interfacial resistance is inversely proportional to the strength of electric field. We developed a model to explain this voltage dependence extending the theory of Warburg impedance in the presence of external electrical field.

We employed the developed tri-layer structures to analyze polymer-ceramic interfacial resistance in case of single Li conducting polymer (polymerized ionic liquid), and the same polymer doped with Li salt. Ceramic is not permeable for anions of the salt leading to blocking of mobile anions at the interface. Surprisingly, interfacial resistance of tri-layer samples doped with Li salt appears to be lower than that of sample with pure polymerized ionic liquid, although bulk polymer conductivity remains the same. This result is unexpected because blocking anions should have increased interfacial resistance and remains a puzzle.

In addition to these scientific achievements, the NSF-BSF funding significantly contributed to the development of human resources and education and international collaboration (with Israel). One graduate student, one postdoctoral associate (female) and one research staff were actively involved in this study. Research staff got a research professor position at the University of Tennessee – Oak Ridge Innovation Institute (UT-ORII) and started his independent research career. Knowledge developed during this project was included in graduate courses taught by the PIs at UT.

 


Last Modified: 01/16/2025
Modified by: Alexei Sokolov
